Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mechatronics engineers and technicians play a critical role in advanced manufacturing, and there is a growing need for skilled workers in this field regionally and nationally. In response, South Central College (SCC) is creating a distance learning education program (iMEC) that builds on its existing Mechatronics Engineering Technology (MET) face-to-face program. The MET program at SCC is a direct result of strong partnerships with regional industry members, which provide industrial expertise and resources to support this project. To achieve this, the objectives are to 1) develop and implement the online remote access degree program, 2) create a regional system with educational and industry partners and through outreach, and 3) build the institutional capacity of SCC's MET program.

This project utilizes online and simulation tools and remote access methods to adapt its existing MET lectures and laboratories to students across the state of Minnesota. Through the remote access of laboratory systems distance learning students develop troubleshooting skills that are necessary for mechatronics engineering technicians. The iMEC program is leveraging the state-of-the-art mechatronics resources at SCC to provide access to broad groups of students. The iMEC program is integrating best practices for both distance and face-to-face learning from partners at Moultrie Technical College and the Florida Advanced Technological Education Center (FLATE). The project evaluation includes a comparison of the student success and student perception between the face-to-face and distance learners and an evaluation process to improve the iMEC program.

The iMEC program provides advanced manufacturing distance education as well as educational and career pathways into MET for traditional and non-traditional students and broadens the participation of students from underrepresented groups, including women, minorities, and veterans, and geographically dispersed students. The innovative methods for distance learning used in the iMEC program can be adapted by other engineering and technology programs and addresses the demands of future engineering education. The iMEC program serves as an education model that integrates continuous quality improvement and best practices and adapts curricula and instructional delivery models through innovative methods to bring distance education to students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
South Central College’s (SCC) distance education delivery model (iMEC) gives students the opportunity to access instructors, participate in classes and experience hands-on training in Mechatronics courses without physically being on campus. The college developed iMEC using online curriculum, simulation lab kits and remote access delivery methods to allow institutions to share curriculum and specialized equipment across multiple campuses and with industry partners.

Because of the high cost of equipment in STEM laboratories, it is difficult for colleges and universities to duplicate STEM laboratories on every college campus. Additionally, industry found distance and travel to be barriers for employees and traditional students who want to enhance their skills through hands-on training.  To help address these barriers, SCC considered how the college’s existing Mechatronics program could be expanded to support even more students and industry partners. Building off the successful on-campus program, the Mechatronics staff embarked on creating a distance-delivery system that would provide a comparable learning experience for students.

Outcomes and Finding

South Central College’s iMEC team developed systems that incorporated technology that directly benefits advanced, second-year Mechatronics students. These advanced systems are known as Independent Remote Experiment Automation Lab (iREAL) machines. Over time, it became apparent that we should also design machines/training units that aligned with our first-year courses as well. These new training units still use the data acquisition technology boards we designed to communicate with distant learners on the SMC MAP 200 trainers.

Expanding our iMEC offerings to include lower-level courses allows the iMEC team to capture different demographics; for example middle and high school students and those attending Experience Camps. These students can sample many aspects of mechatronics before stepping into the formal classroom.

As a result, we incorporated the Data Acquisition Controller iREAL machines into other mechatronics courses. Modifications were made as necessary to electrically fit the new training units. These units include the following SCC-designed components: a Frequency Drive Module that interfaces with our Workstations for Hands on Learning Experiments (WHOLE) kits, Sensor and Control Modules, an Overhead Gantry Robot System, an AC Motor Vibration Detection System, and an AC Motor Overload System. A group of returning students has signed up to work on some of the systems listed above during the fall 2017 semester. Once the final adjustments have been made, the Web cameras will be fitted back onto the systems.

Innovation

Mechatronics is an area of study in which activities such as troubleshooting and diagnostics of complex systems are best acquired through hands-on learning. In addition to traditional lectures and other on-line learning tools, iMEC has addressed these concerns with two unique innovations:

1. iMEC Independent Remote Experiment Automation Lab (iREAL) Machine

The iREAL systems are designed to make hardware available to distance learners to complete labs that are an integral part of their course of study. An overhead camera streams live images, giving the student real-time feedback on the system’s performance. An HMI, developed with National Interments LabVIEW, acts as a control portal for the student to interact with the iREAL system. The student also has the ability to monitor and manipulate Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) software in an effort to create programs, troubleshoot, and solve iREAL system issues based on a series of labs.

2. Workstations for Hands-on Learning Experiments (WHOLE) Kits

The WHOLE kits include all the materials and components necessary for the distance learner to complete the Mechatronic labs in the same manner as face-to-face students. Depending on the course of study, kits include tools, frame/backplane, air tank, PLCs, electronic/mechanical components, and the instructions necessary to build upon weekly progressive labs. These kits have been integrated into three of the first-year Mechatronics courses.

When students enroll in a relevant Mechatronics class, they purchase the WHOLE kit from the SCC bookstore and it is sent to their locale. As a result, students have the ability to follow-along on lesson plans and class activities in their living room or work area—no need for travel, no need for an expensive lab.

Local education institutions are saved from the expense of putting together a lab themselves. Lab equipment and instructors are expensive and hard to find. In many cases, it is not reasonable to invest capital in locating equipment, instructors, and other resources in multiple remote geographic areas to accommodate a small number of students.

 


Last Modified: 08/25/2017
Modified by: Doug Laven
